prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Mapping the Dense Star Forming Gas in NGC 3256
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We propose a total of 1,42 hours to obtain 1.5" resolution HCN (1-0) and HCO+ (1-0) maps toward a merger remnant, NGC 3256, previously observed in CO (1-0) using ALMA. The main purpose of this proposal is to map the distribution of the HCN/HCO+ emission at < 1 kpc resolution in order to identify the dense gas directly fueling the star formation activity. This will be an initial pilot survey that focuses on five sources, and the rest of the sources will be observed in later cycles after a successful Cycle 2 campaign. The particular analyses we intend to perform are (1) investigating the distribution and kinematics of the dense molecular gas at < 1 kpc resolution in the context of molecular disk formation, and (2) evaluating the size of the dense gas disk in the context of galaxy merger models.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We request a total of 1.42 hours to image the HCN (1-0) and HCO+(1-0) lines (band 3) in a merger remnant, NGC 3256. We will use 1.875 GHz bandwidth per spectral window in the dual polarization mode. We can observe the HCN (1-0) and HCO+ (1-0) lines using two spectral windows, simultaneously. We propose a single field with the galactic center as the phase center. The primary beam is 70" at 88 GHz, which is large enough to cover the distribution of the dense star forming gas because the dense molecular gas is usually distributed within regions where the diffuse molecular gas such as the CO (1-0), and the CO (1-0) emission is distributed within 15" central region in our ALMA Cycle 0 images. We will use the same angular resolution (1.5") as our Cycle 0 CO (1-0) images. We request the dense gas mass sensitivity M(dense) = 3×10^4 Msun that is comparable to the M(H2) sensitivity achieved in Cycle 0 (assuming L(CO)/L(HCN) = 14 and M(dense) = 10×L(HCN); Gao & Solomon 2004). This yields a one sigma sensitivity of 0.52 mJy/beam in 20 km/s velocity resolution. The time required to reach the sensitivity is 1.42 hours including calibration overhead, according to the sensitivity calculator of the OT. In general, the HCN (1-0) emission is weaker than the HCO+(1-0) in the whole of a galaxy except for the core of an AGN and the X-ray dominated regions (e.g., Kohno et al. 2001). From the ALMA CO (1-0) maps with 6.4" angular resolution, we assume a beam filling factor of 1 and estimate that the peak flux seen in the CO (1-0) map with 1.5 angular resolution is 426 mJy/beam in 20 km/s velocity resolution. Assuming that the HCN line width is a half of the CO line width and that the luminosity ratio L(CO)/L(HCN) is 14 (Gao & Solomon 2004), the estimated average flux density of the HCN (1-0) is 36.2 mJy/beam in each channel with 20 km/s velocity resolution. Thus the request sensitivity yields to detect the peak flux of the HCN (1-0) and HCO+ (1-0) with S/N > 70.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Mapping the Dense Star Forming Gas in NGC 3597
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We propose a total of 1.40 hours to obtain 1.5" resolution HCN (1-0) and HCO+ (1-0) maps toward a merger remnant, NGC 3597, previously surveyed in CO (1-0) using ALMA. The main purpose of this proposal is to map the distribution of the HCN/HCO+ emission at < 1 kpc resolution in order to identify the dense gas directly fueling the star formation activity, and to examine its relation to the beam-matched distribution of the diffuse CO (1-0) emitting gas. This will be an initial pilot survey that focuses on six sources, and the rest of the sources will be observed in later cycles after a successful Cycle 2 campaign. The particular analyses we intend to perform are (1) investigating the distribution and kinematics of the dense molecular gas at < 1 kpc resolution in the context of molecular disk formation, and (2) evaluating the size of the dense gas disk in the context of galaxy merger models.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We request a total of 1.40 hours to image the HCN (1-0) and HCO+(1-0) lines (band 3) in a merger remnant, NGC 3597. We will use 1.875 GHz bandwidth per spectral window in the dual polarization mode. We can observe the HCN (1-0) and HCO+ (1-0) lines using two spectral windows, simultaneously. We propose a single field with the galactic center as the phase center. The primary beam is 70" at 88 GHz, which is large enough to cover the distribution of the dense star forming gas because the dense molecular gas is usually distributed within regions where the diffuse molecular gas such as the CO (1-0), and the CO (1-0) emission is distributed within 15" central region in our ALMA Cycle 0 images. We will use the same angular resolution (1.5") as our Cycle 0 CO (1-0) images so that a direct comparison of the line ratios can be obtained. We request the dense gas mass sensitivity M(dense) = 5×10^4 Msun that is comparable to the M(H2) sensitivity achieved in Cycle 0 (assuming L(CO)/L(HCN) = 14 and M(dense) = 10×L(HCN); Gao & Solomon 2004). This yields a one sigma sensitivity of 0.52 mJy/beam in 20 km/s velocity resolution. The time required to reach the sensitivity is 1.40 hours including calibration overhead, according to the sensitivity calculator of the OT. In general, the HCN (1-0) emission is weaker than the HCO+(1-0) in the whole of a galaxy except for the core of an AGN and the X-ray dominated regions (e.g., Kohno et al. 2001). The peak flux of the CO (1-0) emission in 20 km/s velocity resolution is 78.6 mJy/beam. Assuming that the HCN line width is a half of the CO line width and that the luminosity ratio L(CO)/L(HCN) is 14 (Gao & Solomon 2004), the estimated average flux density of the HCN (1-0) is 6.69 mJy/beam in each channel with 20 km/s velocity resolution. Thus the request sensitivity yields to detect the peak flux of the HCN (1-0) and HCO+ (1-0) with S/N > 13.

The main purpose of this proposal is to map the distribution of the HCN/HCO+ emission at < 1 kpc resolution in order to identify the dense gas directly fueling the star formation activity, and to examine its relation to the beam-matched distribution of the diffuse CO (1-0) emitting gas. We will use 1.875 GHz bandwidth per spectral window in the dual polarization mode. We can observe the HCN (1-0) and HCO+ (1-0) lines using two spectral windows, simultaneously. We propose a single field with the galactic center as the phase center. We will use the same angular resolution (1.5") as our Cycle 0 CO (1-0) images so that a direct comparison of the line ratios can be obtained. We request the dense gas mass sensitivity M(dense) = 2×10^5 Msun that is comparable to the M(H2) sensitivity achieved in Cycle 0 (assuming L(CO)/L(HCN) = 14 and M(dense) = 10×L(HCN); Gao & Solomon 2004). This yields a one sigma sensitivity of 0.52 mJy/beam in 20 km/s velocity resolution. Thus the request sensitivity yields to detect the peak flux of the HCN (1-0) and HCO+ (1-0) with S/N > 20.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Mapping the Densse Star Forming Gas in AM 2055-425
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We propose a total of 1.50 hours to obtain 1.5" resolution HCN (1-0) and HCO+ (1-0) maps toward a merger remnant, NGC AM 2055-425, previously surveyed in CO (1-0) using ALMA. The main purpose of this proposal is to map the distribution of the HCN/HCO+ emission at < 1 kpc resolution in order to identify the dense gas directly fueling the star formation activity, and to examine its relation to the beam-matched distribution of the diffuse CO (1-0) emitting gas. We will use the same angular resolution (1.5") as our Cycle 0 CO (1-0) images so that a direct comparison of the line ratios can be obtained. This yields a one sigma sensitivity of 0.52 mJy/beam in 20 km/s velocity resolution. prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Mapping the Dense Star Forming Gas in AM 2246-490
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We propose a total of 1.86 hours to obtain 1.5" resolution HCN (1-0) and HCO+ (1-0) maps toward a merger remnant, AM 2246-490, previously surveyed in CO (1-0) using ALMA. The main purpose of this proposal is to map the distribution of the HCN/HCO+ emission at < 1 kpc scale in order to identify the dense gas directly fueling the star formation activity, and to examine its relation to the beam-matched distribution of the diffuse CO (1-0) emitting gas. We will use 1.875 GHz bandwidth per spectral window in the dual polarization mode. We can observe the HCN (1-0) and HCO+ (1-0) lines using two spectral windows, simultaneously. Thus the request sensitivity yields to detect the peak flux of the HCN (1-0) and HCO+ (1-0) with S/N > 9.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: It has been long predicted from numerical simulations that a major merger of two disk galaxies results in a formation of a spheroid-dominated early-type galaxy. Contrary to this classical scenario of galaxy merger evolution, recent high-resolution simulations that include more realistic gas physics have shown that not all of the major mergers will become an early-type galaxy, but some will reemerge as a disk dominated late-type galaxy. We have studied a total sample of 37 optically selected advanced merger remnants in the CO (1-0) line which includes our own ALMA cycle 0 data. We found that 65% of the sources are forming molecular disks with a variety of sizes (radius = 1.1 kpc - 9.3 kpc), but it is impossible to know whether these molecular disks will form stars because the CO only traces the diffuse/cold molecular gas. In this regard, we request 9 hours of ALMA time to observe 6 optically-selected advanced merger remnants in the HCN/HCO+(1-0) lines in order to study the dense gas properties in these forming disks, and thoroughly compare the dense gas properties with the cold gas traced in CO and stellar properties traced in K-band images.
